properties.detail: Chris and Molly created a commercial service strategy that outlined a framework of necessary and appropriate criteria for the park to evaluate existing and proposed commercial activities, and identified high-priority commercial service opportunities.

Claire and Phillip analyzed leasing options for underutilized park assets, including completing an inventory of existing potential structures and their current uses, a market analysis of surrounding rental rates and leased properties, an activity based costing model to assist the park in determining resources needed to implement, and a detailed implementation strategy.

Lisa and Mary improved cost estimation by analyzing historical cost estimation error rates, identifying error drivers, and building new cost estimation tools to reduce future error; they also created a foundational workforce strategy that identified how to maintain mission-critical activities while building new digital capabilities.

properties.type: Special Use Permit Improvement & Land Lease Evaluation
properties.detail: Matt and Tony updated APPA special use permit (SUP) processes to reduce the burden on staff time, collect revenue at a more appropriate level, and streamline coordination with implanting partners like the Appalachian Trail Conservancy by interviewing stakeholders, evaluating SUP pricing, building process flows, checking policy compliance, and projecting potential cost recovery.

Loyd and Nathan developed an analytical framework and scoring metrics for the park to develop parkwide facility and infrastructure reinvestment priorities according to park goals, and used it to recommend strategic project initiatives for the park to develop as they develop a 5-year facilities plan.

Julia and Nick determined the employee demand for park housing units and recommended additional residential and non-residential park facilities for conversion into housing, with the goal of alleviating recruitment and retention challenges by providing access to more housing.

Daniel and Joseph kicked off a workforce and budget planning process, which included holding multiple facilitated sessions with state and nonprofit partners, analyzing gaps and strategic tensions, codifying a position management strategy, and developing tools for the park to use to weigh strategies that would reduce REDW personnel costs as a percent of their total base budget.

Sarah and Stefan built a formal project management organization and process for facilities project implementation based on past funding and workload trends, extensive in-park interviews, and the creation of best practice case studies from across the NPS.
